9.1.19  2:41 am   I auditioned for jazz combos on piano, but since I included bass and drums in my audition video, I'm now playing drums in a jazz combo.  How do I learn to keep from dragging the tempo when I mostly have to practice alone?  I always tend to try and follow instead of lead, probably from playing along to recordings and also being more of a pianist/non-drummer.  The cats are killin and I don't wanna let them down :(

      if you are really always on the slow side, then i guess the simple solution would be to play a little faster

9.1.19  1:24 am   8.29.19 7:34 pm How The Fuck?

      it's RGB. the first 2 digits are red, the middle 2 is green, the last 2 is blue. it's hexidecimal, but let's pretend for a moment it's regular. higher number is brighter. so 00 00 00 would be no red, no green, no blue. so that means totally black. 99 00 00 means a lot of red, no green, no blue. so that's red. 99 00 55 means red with a little bit of blue. so maybe magenta. But all this is slightly false because the numbers are actually supposed to be hexidecimal. which means instead of 0123456789, it's 0123456789abcdef. so 00 is the least and ff is the most. so 00FF00 is full green, 0000FF is full blue, 0000EE is almost full blue, and FFFFFF is full white. 888888 is grey. 995555 would be grey with a slightly reddish tint. 'A' comes after 9, so AA5555 would be the same but slightly more red. etc

9.1.19  12:39 am   i'm want to learn to make songs on a DAW, what would you recommend?

     start with something extremely simple. first just master the play and stop buttons, then the record button. once you've got that then try selecting an instrument

      i hear ableton and fl studio are pretty great, but i'd like to know if those are good for beginners or if another one would be better

     it doesn't really matter. just use the one that's easiest for you to obtain. if you already have one, then definitely just use that

9.1.19  12:37 am   do you write "ah" like "aaaaa," aaaaah", "@@@@@," or differently?

     i write ah like ah. i also write aaaaa like aaaaa

      i usually see you write it like "ah," i think that's the normal way to write it. everyone says they don't understand what i mean by "aaaaa," but i like to write "aaaaa" way more than "aaaaah." it's frustrating. maybe i should try "@@@@@"

      each one of those has a slightly different flavor

9.1.19  12:09 am   i just started my first year of law school. how in the hell do i survive?

      bring plenty of food and water, and warm blankets

8.31.19  5:43 pm   i heard you have perfect pitch,

     not to be confused with perfectly good relative pitch, which i do have, absolute pitch is something i do not absolutely have, but over the years i have developed an extremely good way to fake it to a 95% level of reliability

      but i also heard you started musical training at age 10

     2

      and that you are completely self trained. were you just born with it ?

     absolute pitch is not so important, and i was not even raised to believe it was particularly possible. then later in life i became disappointed that i didn't prioritize that at an earlier age. i have been able to hijack my strong permanent absolute memory of C to essentially appear to have absolute pitch, at least as good as anyone i've ever met who claims to have it. so that will have to be good enough

      and has it ever helped your music making ?

      it can be useful if i am listening to a song that does some super slick modulations, for example if i am doubting if we're now in A or D, that would be easy to mess up except with my new tricks i'll always be on board
